docs.lead_paragraph: EPPS--Roselyn Payne, M.D. The Board of Directors of Mutual of America Life Insurance Company, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of their colleague and friend, Roselyn Payne Epps, M.D. Dr. Epps was an esteemed member of the Board of Directors since 1992 and served with distinction on the Audit, Executive, Long-Range Planning, Product and Marketing and Technology Committees. She was appointed Chair of the Technology Committee in 2001 and in that role was a passionate advocate of the ever increasing importance of technology to the continued success of Mutual of America. Roselyn Epps was an accomplished physician and was recognized nationally and internationally for her life's work in pediatrics and the public health sector. She was the first African American National President of the American Medical Women's Association and was recognized in 2013 with the W. Montague Cobb Lifetime Achievement Award, presented by the W. Montague Cobb National Medical Association Institute, in recognition of her extraordinary commitment to academic excellence, the health of the poor and underserved, quality education and national leadership in medicine. During these past 22 years, Dr. Epps played a major role in Mutual of America's development and growth. We who were privileged to have known her will long remember her strength of character, her dedication to service and her commitment to the mission of Mutual of America. Her wisdom and enthusiasm as well as her warmth and friendship will be greatly missed. William J. Flynn Chairman Emeritus Thomas J. Moran Chairman, President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

docs.lead_paragraph: While it is a win for workers, the order signed last week by Mayor Bill de Blasio offers more exemptions and covers fewer sectors than he originally promised.

headline.main: In Living Wage Law’s Evolution, a Peek at Policy-Making in the de Blasio Era
headline.print_headline: In Living Wage Law’s Evolution, a Peek at Policymaking in the de Blasio Era

docs.abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column observes that while expansion of living wage law in New York City is a win for workers, order signed by Mayor Bill de Blasio offers more exemptions and covers fewer sectors than he originally promised; holds it provides an intriguing glimpse of policy-making in the de Blasio era.
docs.snippet: While it is a win for workers, the order signed last week by Mayor Bill de Blasio offers more exemptions and covers fewer sectors than he originally promised.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Collen worked with Kaiser Permanente for more than 70 years and started one of the first computer databases for tracking patients’ health.

headline.main: Morris Collen, Pioneer in Computerized Medicine, Dies at 100
headline.print_headline: Morris Collen, 100, Pioneer in Computerized Medicine

docs.abstract: Morris F Collen, physician who was instrumental in developing one of first computer databases for tracking patient health, innovation that became foundation of medical system emulated around the world, dies at age 100.
docs.snippet: Mr. Collen worked with Kaiser Permanente for more than 70 years and started one of the first computer databases for tracking patients’ health.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. is entering his 10th term, and it is one that could define the legacy of the court he leads.

headline.main: Supreme Court’s Robust New Session Could Define Legacy of Chief Justice
headline.print_headline: Supreme Court’s Robust New Session Could Define Legacy of Chief Justice

docs.abstract: Supreme Court is returning to work to face rich and varied docket that may define legacy of Chief Justice John G Roberts Jr, who is entering his 10th term, as well as legacy of court; some of larger issues being considered include whether same-sex marriage is constitutional right and new challenge to Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. is entering his 10th term, and it is one that could define the legacy of the court he leads.

docs.lead_paragraph: The market for training medical assistants is deeply troubling.

headline.main: When Higher Education Doesn’t Deliver on Its Promise
headline.print_headline: When Education Doesn't Deliver on Its Promise

docs.abstract: The Upshot; market for medical assistant education is deeply troubling; federal data that tracks college graduates into job market shows that many people who graduate from such programs struggle to find work, and that those who do work often make little money.
docs.snippet: The market for training medical assistants is deeply troubling.
